channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel-Hamas War: Israeli Video Brings Gaza Hospital to Center of Information War
item.description: The Israeli military released footage showing what it said was Hamas facilities below Gaza’s main children’s hospital, prompting sharp denials from Palestinian health officials.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Al-Shifa hospital, where displaced Palestinians have taken shelter, in Gaza City last week.

item.title: Ukraine Indicts Officials Linked to Efforts to Investigate the Bidens
item.description: Three officials were accused of operating at the behest of Russian intelligence when they aligned with efforts by Rudolph W. Giuliani to tie the Biden family to corruption in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: Oleksandr Dubinsky after a news conference in Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv, in 2021.

item.title: As Xi Heads to San Francisco, Chinese Propaganda Embraces America
item.description: After years of anti-American propaganda, the softer, warmer depiction of relations with the United States has left some Chinese social media users confused or amused.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Xi Jinping, then-vice president of China, in Iowa in 2012 in a tractor with a farmer.

item.title: Thousands of Ukrainian Refugees Risk Returning Home for Medical Care
item.description: Hundreds of thousands who fled after Russia invaded make brief visits back, often to reconnect with family but also for health care that can be cheaper and more familiar.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Oksana Parafeniuk for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liudmyla Gurenchuk, a Ukrainian who lives in France, having an ultrasound scan in Kyiv, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Hard Hit by Loss of Thai and Palestinian Workers, Israeli Farmers Call for Volunteers
item.description: After the Oct. 7 terror attack, Israel banned Gazan farm workers, and many other foreign laborers returned to their home countries.
item.dc:creator: Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yuval Shragian, on his farm in Tzofit, Israel, is one of many farmers struggling to find laborers since the Oct. 7 terrorist attack, in which 32 Thai workers were killed and 25 were kidnapped.

item.title: Russia Pardons Man Convicted in Journalist’s Murder in Return for Ukraine Service
item.description: The lawyer of Sergei G. Khadzhikurbanov, who was sentenced to 20 years in prison for helping to organize the killing of Anna Politkovskaya, said he had been pardoned by President Vladimir V. Putin.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko
item.media:description: Sergei G. Khadzhikurbanov, a former law enforcement officer, at a hearing in Moscow in 2013.

item.title: David Cameron Brings Experience to UK Government, and an Uneven Record
item.description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak, who has presented himself as a change agent, chose a predecessor, Mr. Cameron, as his foreign secretary. But he comes with political baggage.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: David Cameron, former prime minister of Britain, leaving 10 Downing Street in London on Monday, after being appointed foreign secretary.

item.title: New Video Suggests Elizabeth Tsurkov, Academic Kidnapped in Iraq, Is Alive
item.description: Elizabeth Tsurkov, who is believed to be held by a pro-Iranian Shiite militia, was shown in an unauthenticated video speaking about the Israeli hostages held in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:description: A 2017 image of the kidnapped Israeli-Russian academic Elizabeth Tsurkov. Ms. Tsurkov is being held by the Iran-linked armed group Kataib Hezbollah.

item.title: Behind Public Assurances, Xi Jinping Has Spread Grim Views on U.S.
item.description: Speeches by the Chinese leader show how he was bracing for an intensifying rivalry with the United States from early in his rule.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley
item.media:description: China’s leader, Xi Jinping, at a news conference with President Barack Obama at the White House in 2015.

item.title: At Tourist Hotels, Israeli Evacuees Plan for Long Stays to Escape Border Attacks
item.description: More than 125,000 Israeli evacuees have been resettled from their communities along the dangerous borders with Lebanon and Gaza in the largest internal displacement in the country’s history.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler, Adam Goldman and Avishag Shaar-Yashuv
item.media:description: Evacuated residents from Kiryat Shmona, in the north of Israel, near the Lebanese border, on the balcony of the Caesar Premier Tiberias Hotel in Tiberias, Israel, on Wednesday.

item.title: What We Know About the Death Toll in Israel From the Hamas-Led Attacks
item.description: Israel’s ability to give an accurate count of how many died in Hamas’s Oct. 7 attack has been complicated by corpses that were mutilated and identifying foreign workers killed in the attacks.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The interior of a house at the Be’eri kibbutz that was overrun by Hamas militants last month.

item.title: Under Pressure, U.K.’s Sunak Tries Another Cabinet Reset With a Swerve to Center
item.description: After more than a year as prime minister, Rishi Sunak, a Conservative, has failed to close a yawning gap in the polls. On Monday he did something new.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Home Secretary Suella Braverman and Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain during a round table about policing at 10 Downing Street, last month.

item.title: Fighting to Govern Myanmar, From a Teeny Office in Washington
item.description: The National Unity Government of Myanmar, formed as an alternative to the junta that orchestrated a 2021 coup, has to battle global apathy and ignorance as it struggles for recognition.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.media:description: U Moe Zaw Oo, the deputy foreign minister in a shadow government seeking recognition as the legitimate leadership of Myanmar, at the group’s American headquarters in Washington.

item.title: Youth Struggle to Find Jobs in South Africa, Where 6 in 10 Are Unemployed
item.description: Portia Stafford has a high school diploma in hospitality and three certificates from job training programs. She is among a generation of ambitious Africans who spend their days chasing an elusive opening.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel and Gulshan Khan
item.media:credit: Gulshan Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Why Rishi Sunak Is on His 3rd Political Makeover
item.description: Rishi Sunak’s reshuffle was a bold attempt to win back more moderate Conservatives. But it could backfire, analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain at a cabinet meeting inside 10 Downing Street on Tuesday.

item.title: Families of Hostages Start a March From Tel Aviv to Jerusalem
item.description: About 100 people plan to march to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s office to pressure him to do whatever it takes to bring their loved ones home, setting up camp each night along the way.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Friends and families of hostages held by Hamas take part in a march from Tel Aviv to the prime minister’s office in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: In a Report Card on Global Warming, Nations Get a Very Poor Grade
item.description: Countries are taking “baby steps,” a U.N. official said. In a separate study, Saudi researchers warned of an “existential crisis” for their nation from rising temperatures.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims in Mecca. A recent study said warming could endanger Saudi Arabian food supplies as well as the health of visitors during the Hajj.

item.title: What to Know About Iceland’s Volcano Eruption and Possible Flight Disruptions
item.description: While the authorities continue to warn for a volcanic eruption, they say that any disruption to air travel will probably be minimal.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: Lava spurting after the eruption in July of a volcano on the Reykjanes Peninsula in Iceland.

item.title: Vivian Silver, Canadian-Israeli Activist, Confirmed Killed in Hamas Attack
item.description: Vivian Silver, 74, a Canadian Israeli, was believed to have been abducted on Oct. 7 but was killed in the initial attacks that day, her son said.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: Protesters holding up images in London last week of people thought to be held hostage, including Vivan Silver, who was confirmed as dead on Monday.

item.title: March for Israel: Jewish Groups Plan Rally in Washington, D.C.
item.description: Educators, artists, students and relatives of some of the hundreds of hostages seized by Hamas are scheduled to appear, along with top U.S. lawmakers.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson
item.media:credit: Haiyun Jiang for The New York Times
item.media:description: The rally on Tuesday comes after large protests across the United States and in world capitals denouncing the Israeli military campaign in Gaza.

item.title: U.S. Manages Expectations of a Breakthrough Before Biden and Xi Meet
item.description: President Biden and President Xi Jinping of China will try to defuse a year of bubbling tensions on Wednesday at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and David E. Sanger
item.media:description: President Biden’s advisers have hinted at only one concrete agreement expected to emerge from his meeting with President Xi Jinping of China.

item.title: What Long-Term Care Looks Like Around the World
item.description: Most countries spend more than the United States on care, but middle class and affluent people still bear a substantial portion of the costs.
item.dc:creator: Jordan Rau
item.media:description: An elder care facility in Tokyo, where long-term care insurance is mandatory for citizens age 40 and over.

item.title: 5th National Climate Assessment Lays Out Climate Threats and Solutions
item.description: A major government assessment lays out both the far-reaching perils of global warming and the cost-effective fixes that are available today.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong
item.media:description: A helicopter fought the Highland fire near Aguana, Calif., on Oct. 31.

item.title: More Than 400 U.S. Officials Sign Letter Protesting Biden’s Israel Policy
item.description: The signers, representing some 40 government agencies, reflect growing internal dissent over the administration’s support of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.category: United States Agency for International Development
item.media:description: Hundreds of signatories from across the U.S. government have now dissented from President Biden and Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken in their support for Israel’s war in Gaza.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Calls to protect hospitals in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Palestinians sheltering inside the Al-Shifa Hospital compound in Gaza City.

item.title: Hamas Says Israeli Hostage Noa Marciano Was Killed in Gaza Bombardments
item.description: The Israeli military released a statement appearing to confirm the authenticity of the video, which it condemned as “psychological terrorism.”
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers last month on patrol near Kibbutz Nahal Oz, on the border with the Gaza Strip. Noa Marciano, an Israeli soldier, was stationed at a lookout post on Kibbutz Nahal Oz on Oct. 7 when Hamas attacked.

item.title: U.N. Says Gaza Fuel Could Run Out by Tuesday, Preventing Aid Distribution
item.description: The lack of fuel, used to operate the fork lifts that unload the goods and the trucks that deliver them, is imperiling the only lifeline for the 2.2 million people in the coastal enclave.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: A truck returning to Egypt from Gaza in Rafah, Egypt, on Sunday after delivering humanitarian aid.

item.title: State Dept. Workers Sign Memos Urging Biden to Call for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The messages urge the Biden administration to press Israel for a cease-fire, according to U.S. officials. Two were said to have been sent in the first week of the war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shelter in Khan Younis, in the south of Gaza, on Saturday.

item.title: At Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital, Death and Despair as Israel’s Forces Arrive
item.description: “I’m watching patients die in front of my eyes,” one doctor at a besieged hospital said, “and I can’t provide them the slightest bit of help.” Israel said its forces were targeting Hamas fighters.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek, Ameera Harouda and Thomas Fuller
item.category: United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Bodies in the courtyard of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Looking to a Biden-Xi Meeting
item.description: Plus how much can trees help fight climate change.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: President Biden and Xi Jinping last met in November 2022.

item.title: Hamas Has Held Some Israeli Hostages Since Before Oct. 7
item.description: Two Israeli citizens taken nearly a decade ago are believed to still be alive. Families are also fighting for the return of the remains of two soldiers killed in 2014.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.media:description: Simha and Lea Goldin, the parents of Hadar Goldin, at a march in 2022 to demand that Hamas release the remains of their son. A soldier, he was killed in Gaza in 2014.

item.title: Dark Hedges: 6 ‘Game of Thrones’ Trees Will Be Cut Down
item.description: Six of the Dark Hedges beech trees, a tourist destination in Northern Ireland for fans of the HBO fantasy series, will be cut down because they are in poor condition, officials said.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:credit: Hazel Thompson for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Dark Hedges, an avenue of beech trees in Northern Ireland, has become a destination for “Game of Thrones” fans.

item.title: Who Is James Cleverly, the UK’s New Home Secretary?
item.description: Cleverly is generally seen as less ideological and more of a team player than his predecessor in the Home Office, Suella Braverman.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: James Cleverly in London in 2020.

item.title: Nepal Is Banning TikTok Over Hate Content, Officials Say
item.description: The small Himalayan nation’s cabinet of ministers said the Chinese-owned app had neglected its repeated requests to curb content that affected “social harmony.”
item.dc:creator: Bhadra Sharma

item.title: Is David Cameron a Member of Parliament?
item.description: Ministers in Britain have to hold a seat in Parliament, but the government can create a place in the House of Lords to satisfy that requirement.
item.dc:creator: Peter Robins and Stephen Castle
item.media:description: The House of Lords in London during the State Opening of Parliament on Nov. 7.

item.title: Biden Strengthens Ties With Indonesia Despite Tensions Over the War in Gaza
item.description: Indonesia’s president, Joko Widodo, visited the White House and appealed to President Biden to call for a cease-fire. Mr. Biden focused instead on their new strategic partnership.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers and Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:description: President Biden and President Joko Widodo of Indonesia met at the White House on Monday.

item.title: Rishi Sunak’s New Cabinet in the U.K.: Updating List
item.description: David Cameron, a former British prime minister, is taking over as foreign secretary.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak on Monday shuffled several members of his government.

item.title: Suella Braverman’s Most Controversial Moments as UK Home Secretary
item.description: Ms. Braverman, who is no stranger to controversy, has now been fired from the post of home secretary twice.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Suella Braverman’s hard-line positions on issues like immigration have often stoked divisions in Britain.

item.title: Chevron Restarts Gas Production on Platform Near Gaza Strip
item.description: The energy giant had halted operations at the offshore facility on request from Israel’s government shortly after the attacks by Hamas militants last month.
item.dc:creator: Stanley Reed
item.media:description: The Tamar natural gas platform in the Mediterranean Sea, off the coast of Israel, in 2015.

item.title: Ukraine Says Russian Officers Are Killed in Melitopol Attack
item.description: In the latest strike, Kyiv said three Russian officers were killed in a bombing in the southern city of Melitopol.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A Russian flag in Melitopol, a city in southern Ukraine that is occupied by Russian forces.

item.title: Gaza’s Al-Shifa Hospital Is ‘No Longer Functioning,’ WHO Says
item.description: The agency warned of a “dire and perilous” situation for those trapped inside as Israeli troops battle Hamas fighters nearby.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd and Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: The emergency ward of Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City earlier this month.

item.title: Leila de Lima, Duterte Critic, Is Released on Bail in the Philippines
item.description: Though she was never convicted, Ms. de Lima was detained for six years after she fiercely opposed the Philippine former president’s brutal war on drugs.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Camille Elemia
item.media:description: Leila de Lima before her hearing in Muntinlupa City, the Philippines, on Monday. The court granted her bail plea.

item.title: Chile, Known for Its Wines and Piscos, Turns to Gin
item.description: Distilleries are popping up across the country as Chileans use the versatile spirit to showcase their country’s unique botanicals.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Tomas Munita for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zunda, a microdistillery in the heart of Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Monday Briefing
item.description: The latest from the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost

item.title: U.S. Carries Out Another Round of Airstrikes on Targets Tied to Iran
item.description: Airstrikes hit two facilities in eastern Syria, most likely killing or injuring Iran-backed militia personnel. The United States has blamed such groups for recent attacks against its troops.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The Defense Department released a video of a Nov. 8 airstrike on what it said was a weapons warehouse in eastern Syria linked to Iran-backed militias.

item.title: Israeli Troops Near Gaza’s Al Shifa Hospital, Which Is Struggling to Operate
item.description: Israeli officials say that Hamas has built a complex under Al Shifa, a major Gaza hospital. Hamas denies it is operating from beneath the hospital, whose patients face dire conditions amid power cuts.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Rosenberg, Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman and Vivian Yee
item.media:description: The lights of Al Shifa Hospital in Gaza City last month.

item.title: Netanyahu Sees No Near-Term Role for Palestinian Authority in a Postwar Gaza
item.description: Differing from the U.S. view, the Israeli prime minister also said Israel must retain security control over Gaza so it can be “demilitarized” and “de-radicalized.”
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner, Aaron Boxerman and Thomas Fuller
item.media:credit: Yousef Masoud for The New York Times
item.media:description: Palestinians mourning on Sunday for relatives killed by Israeli airstrikes in Khan Younis, southern Gaza.

item.title: Nonexistent Google Map Trail Prompts Hikers’ Rescues in Canada
item.description: A Canadian search-and-rescue group said it had conducted two missions recently after hikers “may have sought to follow” a nonexistent trail on Google Maps.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch

item.title: Monday Briefing: Conditions Worsen in Gazan Hospitals
item.description: Plus Vegemite’s 100th birthday.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Al-Quds Hospital in Gaza City last month. Israeli tanks and military vehicles have surrounded the hospital, the Palestinian Red Crescent said.

item.title: Hundreds of Thousands Protest Spanish Prime Minister’s Deal With Separatists
item.description: The deal, which grants amnesty to secessionists, is meant to give Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez enough support to form a coalition to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered in Malaga, Spain, on Sunday, to protest the government’s proposed law that would grant amnesty to Catalan separatists.

item.title: 5 U.S. Special Operations Troops Killed in Helicopter Crash in Mediterranean
item.description: The troops were on a refueling training mission when the aircraft crashed off the coast of Cyprus. The episode, which Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said was an accident, is under investigation.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: “We mourn the tragic loss of five U.S. service members during a training accident in the Mediterranean Sea,” Defense Secretary Lloyd J. Austin III said on Sunday.

item.title: Peter Nygard, Former Fashion Mogul, Convicted of Sexual Assault
item.description: The verdict in Toronto concludes the first of Mr. Nygard’s criminal trials in Canada. The 82-year-old also faces charges in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:description: Peter Nygard leaving a Toronto courthouse in a police vehicle in September. Mr. Nygard faces several more pending trials.

item.title: Over 100,000 March in France Against Antisemitism
item.description: The demonstrations in Paris and other cities came amid a rise in tensions in France over the Gaza war and a surge in antisemitic incidents.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Porter and Liz Alderman
item.media:description: The demonstration against antisemitism in Paris on Sunday was called by the leaders of both houses of the French Parliament.

item.title: In Texas, Vietnamese American Shrimpers Must Forge a New Path Again
item.description: They overcame the trauma of war, language barriers and prejudice to become successful shrimpers. But the decline of the industry in America is forcing them to consider other options.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Callaghan O’Hare
item.media:credit: Callaghan O'Hare for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vinh Nguyen fishing for shrimp on his trawler in Matagorda Bay. Mr. Nguyen is one of thousands of Vietnamese refugees who settled along the Gulf Coast after the Vietnam War.

item.title: How Ukraine, With No Warships, Is Thwarting Russia’s Navy
item.description: The commander of Ukraine’s Navy said in a rare interview that the Russian naval blockade of Odesa had been broken. He also described how the war is transforming naval tactics.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pier overlooking the Black Sea in Odesa. Despite its lack of warships, Ukraine has managed to break the Russian blockade of the city.

item.title: The Occupied West Bank: Divided by Faith, United by Fear
item.description: As bloodshed surges around them, an Israeli settler and a Palestinian tour guide search for answers — and a shred of hope.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Installing surveillance cameras above a guard post last week in Tekoa, a settlement in the Israeli-occupied West Bank. Tensions have increased since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.

item.title: Why Vultures Might Just Be the Smartest Birds Above the Block
item.description: The birds are widely reviled for their carrion-eating ways. But an evolutionary history of scavenging has forged a creative, cunning and wide-ranging mind.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Angier
item.media:credit: Shuran Huang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lappet-faced vultures, Shredder and Kenya, residents of the Maryland Zoo in Baltimore.

item.title: Toxic Air Can’t Keep New Delhi’s Joggers and Yoga Fans Inside
item.description: In India’s capital, skipping exercise and the social routines that often come with it is seen as worse than going out and breathing poison.
item.dc:creator: Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Elke Scholiers for The New York Times
item.media:description: Practicing yoga in Lodhi Garden with smog lingering over India’s capital city, New Delhi, on Wednesday.

item.title: Inside the World’s Only Vegemite Factory
item.description: First concocted a century ago, the spread is widely adored by Australians — and loathed by almost everyone else.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Abigail Varney
item.media:credit: Abigail Varney for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jars of Vegemite at the factory in Port Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Gaza Hospitals Near Collapse as Fighting Rages Nearby
item.description: Facing power outages and shortages of food, water and medical supplies, hospitals are struggling just to keep patients alive, Gazan health authorities say.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim, Ameera Harouda and Alan Yuhas
item.media:credit: Khader Al Zanoun/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Al-Shifa Hospital in Gaza City on Friday, where a Gazan taking shelter said, “Everyone is on top of one another, displaced people, wounded people, even the medical staff.”

item.title: Iran and Saudi Arabia Demand Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The leaders of both Islamic countries appeared to put aside their historical animosities at a summit to present a united stand against Israel’s bombardment of the strip after Hamas’s attack.
item.dc:creator: Ahmed Al Omran and Yara Bayoumy
item.media:description: Hissein Brahim Taha, secretary general of the Organization of Islamic Cooperation, Prince Faisal bin Farhan, foreign minister of Saudi Arabia, and Ahmed Aboul Gheit, secretary general of the Arab League, attend a summit in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, on Saturday to discuss the Gaza crisis.

item.title: Hezbollah’s Leader Says His Fighters Will Keep Up Pressure on Israel
item.description: As clashes continue along Israel’s volatile border with Lebanon, Hassan Nasrallah said his group was now trying to hit targets deeper inside Israel with newer and more advanced weapons.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: “The pressure must continue” on Israel, said Hassan Nasrallah, the leader of Hezbollah, during a televised address in Lebanon on Saturday.
